content:
Validator 26 is the hardest, and harder by a wide margin, for a semi-brute-force approach.

By semi-brute-force I mean if you find the prime factorisation, then generate all divisors by calculating all the possible combinations of the prime divisors and making an array of them, then removing the duplicates.

This code got 96% on validators and 100% on tests in a clash (it was silly to not see the 'smart' solution, but when it passed 100% I didn't think about optimising further):

require 'prime'
n = gets.to_i
p = n.prime_division
x = p.flat_map{|i, e| [i]*e }
l = x.size
p(-1)/0 if n <= 1
b = (0...2**l).map{|j| o = ("%0#{l}b" % j).chars.map &:to_i
  (o.zip(x).map{_1*_2} -[0]).reduce(:*) }
f = [1, *b.uniq] - [0, nil]
puts f.size == 3 ? f*" " : -1

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is easy to comprehend and easy to solve.
(p.s. I wonder what a quad-prime problem would look like)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: le jeu proposé est simple à comprendre et est bien adapté pour le clash
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
So basically: get the square root of the number to process and check if it's prime?

I tried to golf it and realized that validator 5 needs to have an identical test, otherwise solutions like this:

n=gets.to_f
k=(2..).find{n%_1<1}
puts n/k/k==1?[1,k,k*k]*" ":-1

can pass all tests but not that validator (stuck in that infinite loop at the second line). It can be easily fixed but there's no way to know it.

Ungolfed in cpp that would be sth like:

https://bpa.st/M37AW

If you uncomment those 4 lines you will pass everything.

Goal section
* Please mention that the divisors should be output in ascending order.

Output section
* Please change "Print 1 Line." to "<<Line 1:>>".

Stub generator
* Please change x to n for consistency.

* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.
Hmm I don't think there's an identical test to 1. Maybe I should put it in Test instead of Validator?
If you want to be extra evil, you can make both the final test and validator case account for n=1.
It would be nice to add a test that is of similar size to Validator 26, and with a similar amount of divisors (i.e. not Tri-Prime).

I meant literally the same test as in:

Test 5: 1, Output 1
Validator 5: 1, Output 1;

If you put it only in a test you could pass with that solution had you known the hidden information that 1 won't be validated (admitted, very unlikely).

The "drawnback" is the PHP trick of just print 1, but in this puzzle you would rather print -1 anyway if you felt that lazy.
